question.title: How to Customize Validation for Built-in Annotations in Spring
question.body:
I'm encountering an issue with Spring Boot Validation. I'm currently using Spring Boot version 2.4.4 and hibernate-validator version 5.1.0.Final. When validating with javax.validation.constraints.NotBlank, the validation always "succeeds", even when the value is null or an empty string.

After some investigation, I found that the problem arises because the version of Hibernate I’m using matches the annotation org.hibernate.validator.constraints.NotBlank, which causes my javax annotations to be ignored. I attempted to create a custom JavaxNotBlankValidation and inject it into the container, but it didn’t work as expected.

Is there a way to define a Validation for the existing javax annotation without creating a new one (e.g., my.custom.annotation.NotBlank) and still have it function properly?

PS: During my investigation, I realized that the version of hibernate-validator is outdated. When I upgraded to version 6.1.0.Final, this issue was resolved. However, due to various resasons, my request to update the dependency version was declined, so I must continue working with the current version.

answers.body: Use @org.hibernate.validator.constraints.NotBlank Explicitly in your class. This annotation is fully supported in 5.1.0, and will behave correctly.

question_comments.body: If you are on Spring Boot 2.4.4 and are using hibernate-validator version 5.1.0 you already have a dependency mess and meaning that you are manually managing dependencies. Spring Boot 2.4.4 uses (and is tested with) hibernate validator 6.1.7. So I wouldn't request an upgrade I would simply ditch the dependency and instead include spring-boot-starter-validation as you should have done in the first place. Which makes me worried about your whole project and the other dependencies in there as well.
Why doesn't your custom annotation work? This guide for example, has always been working like a charm for me.
